tips.title: Tips for choosing a domain
tips.description: A few simple guidelines to help you find the right fit

items.title: Keep it short and memorable
items.desc: Shorter domains are easier to remember, type, and share. Aim for 2-3 words maximum if possible.

items.title: Make it easy to spell
items.desc: Avoid complex spellings or numbers that could confuse people. If you have to explain how to spell it, consider another option.

items.title: Choose .com when possible
items.desc: People naturally assume .com first. If your ideal .com is taken, consider a different name rather than settling for an unusual extension.

items.title: Think long-term
items.desc: Your domain might outlive your first product idea. Choose something that gives you room to grow and evolve.

items.title: Say it out loud
items.desc: Will people understand it when you say it? Does it sound natural in conversation? This matters more than you think.

items.title: Check social media too
items.desc: See if matching social handles are available. Consistency across platforms helps people find and remember you.

items.question: What if my ideal domain is taken?
items.answer: This happens more often than you'd think. Try adding a descriptive word (like "get", "try", or "app"), consider a different extension like .co or .io, or rethink the name entirely. Sometimes a taken domain leads you to an even better name you wouldn't have considered otherwise.

items.question: Should I buy multiple domain extensions?
items.answer: It depends on your goals. If you're a Turkish business, securing both .com and .com.tr makes sense. But you don't need to buy every possible extension—focus on protecting the ones that matter most to your customers.

items.question: Can I change my domain later?
items.answer: Yes, you can always register a new domain and redirect your old one. But changing domains can affect SEO and confuse existing customers, so it's worth taking time to choose carefully now rather than rushing.

items.question: How long does domain registration take?
items.answer: Registration is instant for most extensions. As soon as your payment goes through, the domain is yours. Some country-specific extensions might require verification, but we'll guide you through that if needed.

items.question: Do I actually own the domain?
items.answer: Yes. Completely. When you register a domain with us, you're the legal owner. You can transfer it to another registrar anytime, point it anywhere, or sell it. We're just the registrar—you're the owner.

items.question: Will the renewal price suddenly increase?
items.answer: No. We show you the renewal price before you buy. That's the price you'll pay next year. Registry prices can change (they're set by organizations like Verisign, not us), but we'll always notify you in advance and honor what we promised.

items.question: Can I transfer my domain anytime?
items.answer: Yes. After 60 days from registration (an ICANN rule, not ours), you can transfer your domain to any registrar. We don't lock you in. We don't make it complicated. If you want to leave, we'll help you do it smoothly.

items.question: What if my perfect domain is taken?
items.answer: It happens. We'll help you find alternatives—different TLDs, creative variations, or brandable options. Sometimes what feels like a setback leads to a better name. If you want help brainstorming, just ask. We're good at this.

items.question: Can you help me choose a domain?
items.answer: Absolutely. Choosing a domain can feel overwhelming. Talk to us—we'll ask about your business, help you think through options, and guide you toward something that feels right. No pressure, no upselling. Just honest advice.

process.title: How domain transfer works
process.subtitle: Five simple steps from start to finish

step1.title: Unlock your domain
step1.description: Log into your current registrar and unlock your domain. This is usually in domain settings or security options.

step2.title: Get your authorization code
step2.description: Request an "EPP code" or "auth code" from your current provider. They'll email it to you—usually within minutes.

step3.title: Start the transfer with us
step3.description: Enter your domain and authorization code in our transfer form. We'll verify everything is ready to move.

step4.title: Approve the transfer
step4.description: You'll receive an email asking you to approve the transfer. Click the link to confirm. Your old registrar may also ask for confirmation.

step5.title: Wait for completion
step5.description: Most transfers finish within 5-7 days. We'll email you updates along the way, and you can contact us anytime if you have questions.

items.question: Will my website go down during transfer?
items.answer: No. Your website and email will continue working normally throughout the transfer process. There's zero downtime.

items.question: How long does a transfer take?
items.answer: Most transfers complete within 5-7 days. The exact time depends on how quickly your current registrar approves the transfer request.

items.question: Do I need to unlock my domain first?
items.answer: Yes. Your domain needs to be unlocked in your current registrar's control panel before we can transfer it. We'll guide you through this if needed.

items.question: What if I don't have my authorization code?
items.answer: You can get it from your current registrar's control panel, or contact their support. We can help you locate it if you're not sure where to look.

items.question: Will I lose any time on my domain registration?
items.answer: No. When you transfer, we add a free year to your domain registration. So you actually gain time, not lose it.
